class_description:
ParsePosition is a simple class used by Format
 and its subclasses to keep track of the current position during parsing.
 The parseObject method in the various Format
 classes requires a ParsePosition object as an argument. By design, as you parse through a string with different formats,
 you can use the same ParsePosition, since the index parameter
 records the current position.

Methods.method_description: Create a new ParsePosition with the given initial index.

params.param_description: the reference object with which to compare.

return_description:
true if this object is the same as the obj
          argument; false otherwise.
the index at which an error occurred

Methods.method_description:
Retrieve the index at which an error occurred, or -1 if the
 error index has not been set.

Retrieve the current parse position.  On input to a parse method, this
 is the index of the character at which parsing will begin; on output, it
 is the index of the character following the last character parsed.

return_description: a hash code value for this object

Methods.method_description: Returns a hash code for this ParsePosition.

params.param_description: the index at which an error occurred

Methods.method_description:
Set the index at which a parse error occurred.  Formatters
 should set this before returning an error code from their
 parseObject method.  The default value is -1 if this is not set.

return_description: a string representation of this object

Methods.method_description: Return a string representation of this ParsePosition.
